p:
The basic reproductive number R
0 was in general higher for A(H3N2) (1.6; range: 1.3–2.0) than A(H1N1) (1.4; 1.1–1.8) and B (1.4; 1.1–1.8). Estimated R
0 for the A(H1N1) pandemic in mid-July 2009 was 1.5 (95% CI: 1.3, 1.8), similar to previous estimates [ 46]. The mean effective reproductive number R
e , while fluctuated over time ( Fig 3B), did average to unity over the 20-year study period for all types/subtypes. The estimated infectious period was slightly longer for A(H3N2) (3.0; 2.6–4.3 days) and B (3.1; 2.2–4.1 days) than A(H1N1) (2.6; 2.2–3.8 days).
